text: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis in atopic diseases : a study with allergen - specific human helper T cells .
BACKGROUND : Cytokines produced by helper T cells are intimately involved in chronic allergic diseases associated with eosinophilic inflammation .

OBJECTIVE : We investigated the production of <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a potent growth factor and chemotactic factor for eosinophils , by CD4+ T lymphocytes in patients with asthma .

METHODS : Allergen - specific T cell clones and T cell hybridomas were established from the peripheral blood lymphocytes of patients with asthma , and the responses to various stimuli were determined .

RESULTS : After nonspecific stimulation , <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by CD4+ T cells from both atopic and nonatopic subjects with asthma was significantly enhanced compared with that by cells from healthy controls .

text: Peripheral blood mononuclear cells from atopic asthma patients both proliferated and produced <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> after incubation with mite allergen , suggesting that mite - specific helper T cells were involved in the eosinophilic inflammation of atopic asthma .

text: A human <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter / enhancer luciferase gene construct transfected into <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - producing T cell clones was clearly transcribed after stimulation , indicating that the 515 base pair <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene segment upstream of the coding region was sufficient to respond to activating signals in human helper T cells .
